Greetings Freshmen!

Hope you are enjoying your campus life. We have come to know that there is a need for study material among you all. So we have compiled the material from past few years to help you all out.

The drive contains folders for each of the courses offered this semester and the folders each contain a 'Readme' file which will you a rough description on the course and/or the contents of the folder. The changes And modifications made will be updated to you in the Readme files. We will be updating the drive regularly as need be.

PFA the drive link.

Freshers Study Material


The drive contains extensive material for preparation for the examinations, but it is never enough. We therefore want to increase the content available to all of you. We request you to upload any Tutorial test papers that you must have received from your respective book - pop/mom. Any help would be appreciated.

Freshers Study Material Upload


A Link of Google form for Grievances and Suggestions is also attached below

Grievances Form


Also, we would urge you all to go out and attend your classes and not misuse the institute's attendance policy.

For any queries, you can contact on WhatsApp .


Warm Regards,

Aman Garg
B.E.(Hons.) Chemical Engineering

Makeup Classes
  	
PDF document Timetable WP.pdf

Dear Students

Please submit the makeup applications (hardcopy) to Mr. K G Daiya in the new workshop. The application must contain your details, the reason (with proof) of absence, and the name of the shop for which the makeup is required. The applications will be reviewed and only the genuine cases will be considered. 

Late registered students- You may have missed 3-4 classes due to late registration. Submit the makeup application mentioning the name of the shops you have missed. You can attend regular class of any section (if you are free) during the week and can perform the makeup experiments along with the regular students. Please discuss this with Mr. K G Daiya at the time of application and receive a consent from him. At the time of class, inform the instructor/technician that you are attending a makeup class. I am attaching the workshop schedule for your convenience.

BIRLA INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY & SCIENCE, PILANI 

NOTICE ANNOUNCEMENT OF MID SEM (OPEN BOOK) – REGULAR 










 Answer Part A in question paper itself in the space provided. 

 Answer Part B in the answer book. 

 Submit both part A and Part B. 


 Text book and Thermodynamic property tables from 7th edition and personal handwritten class notes are allowed. Photocopy of other’s notes is NOT allowed. 

 Make up will be given to only genuine cases. Prior permission is necessary for make-up. 

 Strictly follow seating arrangement. The team will not be responsible for answerbook of the student, if he/she is not seating in the assigned room. 


(Instructor-In-Charge)

Rescheduling extra class of 19/11/2019
  	

Dear Students,





See this post in context

Greetings!

I hope your comprehensive exam preparations are going well. The last few days till the exams commence are essential for revisiting the topics and for making the concepts concrete. I have thereby compiled various academic resources including concept map, chapter review, lecture slides, PDFs of textbooks, reference and lecture videos.

This drive mostly contains resources which are not available on SU app.To give a little assistance, I have compiled class notes made by many brilliant 2018 batch students who have done exceptionally well in the courses for which their notes have been given. There was a very popular demand for this initiative last year. Therefore, I felt a need to implement this for our fresher batch, especially for CP and General Biology as class notes are the most integral part for these examinations. This link also contains the new workshop manual, since it is very hard to find. It also contains some of the current year's physics lab comprehensive exam answer sheets to help the students who are yet to give the exam. I assure you that the material provided in this link is reliable, however it is not a substitute for class attendance or self study. I suggest you to use these notes as a supplement and not your only means of preparation. This drive will be regularly updated throughout the academic year to give continuous assistance to the students.I hope the hard work you’ve put in helps you to ace the ensuing exams.


Feel free to contact if you require any further assistance. 

 Regards
Ujjwal Gupta 
f2018A2PS1015P



Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani

Rajasthan - 333031

The batch has been allotted keeping in mind the clash with physics lab exam. You will be provided your login IDs/passwords for the portal during the test. Hence, you must attend the right batch and sit in the right lab. 

This is an open book test. You may carry your class notes or text/reference books. Photocopied class notes will not be permitted, and any exchange of notes/books will also not be permitted. Internet access is also not permitted. 



We will be blocking access to your Prithvi accounts around 11 AM tomorrow (17th Nov). If you want to copy your code files with you, please do it beforehand.

11451001002_BIO F111 » Forums » Announcements » Syllabus for Comprehensive Exam
Picture of Rajdeep Chowdhury . . 	
Syllabus for Comprehensive Exam
  	

Dear Students,

General Biology Comprehensive Exam is on 11th Dec- 2.00pm to 5.00pm.


You are allowed to carry your Text Book, Reference Book and Your Own Handwritten Notebook or Notes only. Photocopied notebooks or slides are not allowed. Electronic Gadgets are not allowed.

Please bring your ID card with you. 

The syllabus for the exam includes topics covered till the last lecture class. Detailed specifications are given below-

Chapter 1 (upto page 9); Chapter 3 (Full); Chapter 4 (upto pg 69); Chapter 5 (Full); Chapter 6 (Full); Chapter 7 (Full; includes C3, C4 and CAM- check Reference Book); Chapter 8 (Full including Cancer); Chapter 9 (till Sex Determination in Humans, pg 163); Chapter 10 (upto pg 191), Chapter 11 (excluding, gene reg in bacteria, homeotic genes, DNA microarray),Chapter 12 (excluding pg 232-234), Chapter 13 (pg 253-258), Chapter 15 (full, as self study), Chapter 16 (full), Chapter 17 (as much covered in class), Chapter 18 (Full, excluding pg 347-349) and Chapter 19 (upto pg 370).

Best of luck for your exams.

Thanks

IC

11451001010_MATH F111 » Forums » Announcements » Important instructions regarding the compre exam
Picture of Suresh Kumar . . 	
Important instructions regarding the compre exam
  	

In the compre exam, you will first write closed book exam for 100 min. (75 marks). Write PART A on top right corner of the front page of your closed book answer sheet. 

After submission of the closed book answer sheet, you will receive a new answer sheet for writing open book exam for 80 min. (60 marks). Write PART B on top right corner of the front page of your open book answer sheet.

Begin each question on a fresh page, and do parts of a question in continuation. Write END after the last attempted solution in both the answer sheets.

Do not carry calculator with you in the examination room. Calculator is not allowed. 

In the open book exam, only the text book and hand written (not photocopied) class notes (stapled only) will be allowed.

Write your exam in your allotted examination room only.

All the best!

IC

Hello Bitsians,

 

We are launching the BITS Time-Table Visualizer. It is a customized web-app to view and resolve clashes. You can select the courses you would like to view your timetable according to your preference.


The web-app will save a lot of time and is a better alternative to filling your phone with timetable apps for just a few days while also wasting storage space!


Link for a Web app - BITS Time-table Visualizer (desktop view only)


The web-app creates fancy time-table(s) when one enters the fields and it is easy to use also.

 

With this feature, you can not only save your timetable in an organized way but also make your pre-registration sample timetable(s) and can see if there are any clashes between courses. Hence, it can make your Registration procedure easy.


Tentative Time-Table is attached below. 

 

We hope this initiative helps you with your registration.

11461001003_BITS F110 » Forums » Announcements » EG Lab guidelines
Picture of Gaurav Watts . 	
EG Lab guidelines
  	

Dear Students,


1. The  lab sessions are going to start from Tuesday (January 14). Please refer to the time table for your lab section and timings.

2.Please carry your text book in all the practical lab sessions. You may be asked to solve some practice problems from your textbook in all the lab sessions.

3.Typically, each practical class shall have 45 minutes practice session and 45 minutes for evaluative assignment.

4.  No make-ups are provided for practical lab sessions. Best total - 3 assignment marks will be considered for  grading.

5. Use of internet ,storage devices and mobile phones is strictly prohibited during the lab sessions. A disciplinary action shall be initiated against the student found violating the code of conduct.

7. If you face any problem with the software or system allotted to you in the lab sessions, please report it immediately to your Section Instructors.

8. Save your work at regular intervals to avoid loss of data in case of power outage.

9. All the students are expected to reach the room in time, maximum relaxation may be up to 10 minutes of the start of practical class. Beyond this, a student will not be allowed in, even in the non-evaluative classes.

10. The first three practical classes will be to familiarize students with AutoCAD commands and are “non-evaluative”. However, attendance will be recorded for all non-evaluative sessions also.


Regards,

IC, BITS F110.

Dear All,

Happy new year! 

Now you are already experienced about studies and preparation of exams in BITS Pilani. Yet I felt the need to share some tips with you for the study of Probability and Statistics course that can help you a lot to have the real feel and learning of this important course. 

First you must know and realize very quickly that this course is very very important course having enormous applications in every discipline of science and engineering. For doing any advance course in statistics, this course is a pre-requisite. Feel it a lifetime opportunity to learn this basic and elementary course. So feel yourself motivated to learn the concepts in this course as deep as possible. Once you start listening and reading it carefully,  it is very easy to understand. Trust me you will enjoy it with fun! 

Now I tell you a short/direct path to reach the level of real learning and enjoyment in this course. First read the notes at the link Chapter 2  word by word, and try to learn all the definitions/concepts cleanly. Try to visualize there how things are developed one after the other. These notes are exclusively prepared for your use. These notes carry nice flow of the development of probability concepts in pedagogical and concise manner. Section 2.1 requires only one careful reading to get an idea of the main objective of the course. After that starting from random experiment learn all the definitions/concepts with examples. Do all the examples in writing with understanding of the concepts. I have taught these notes in the first four lectures in the LTC. So you can also listen the impartus lectures to understand these notes conveniently. If still you face any difficulties in understanding something there, you can write me or come to my office 6165-O around 5 PM on any day (except Saturday and Sunday). I will be happy to help you.

These days, I am working on the Chapter 3 where I am trying to give a crisp and clear demonstration of all the discrete probability distributions. I am sure you will enjoy this stuff...
 
I may not be here tomorrow but my words of motivation will always be with you... Will stay in touch with you..

Cheers! 

Suresh

Dr. Suresh Kumar
Associate Professor, Department of Mathematics
BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus, Rajasthan-333031, INDIA.

Dear All,

Many students did not turn up in the recent couple of LTC classes. Probably, they are busy in preparing for quiz etc. But I would like to suggest them not to miss the lecture classes because it can badly affect their conceptual understanding of this course. Learning the ongoing Chapter 3 with clarity is important as it lays the foundation for remaining chapters in this course.

It is well known that no scientist or engineer is complete without statistics. I wish you to be the best in the world. So do not let this opportunity go. Hope you will plan your preparation for the quiz etc. wisely such that you do not miss the classes of this important course, in any case.

This week, after doing a couple of more probability distributions, I will present a summary of this chapter so that you can visualize development of this whole chapter at one go.

See you.

Cheers,

Dr. Suresh Kumar
Associate Professor, Department of Mathematics
BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus, Rajasthan-333031, INDIA.

Greetings from Mathematics Association!
Mathematics Association brings to you an exciting opportunity to showcase your talent all over the world and get a chance to meet the top mathematicians from the world.

The Students and Research Scholars of Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore are organizing an academic event, called LIMIT. It is an Online International Mathematics Competition mainly aimed at High Schoolers and Undergraduates.


LIMIT will provide a platform to the entire student community to assess themselves respective to their contemporaries throughout the world. Last time LIMIT had an overwhelming response from all over the world. This has motivated us to conduct it this year as well.


▫ The competition will be held in April 2020. All the essential dates are on our website. The last date of registration is 15 February 2020.
▫ The registration fee is INR 200 (₹).
▫ There are no venue restrictions, and candidates can appear from anywhere.
▫ Candidates will receive participation certificates, certificates of merit, based on performance. 
▫ We will invite around 50 students based on their performance to a mathematics camp to interact with world-famous mathematicians from all over the country.
▫ Toppers will receive cash prizes and exciting goodies.

Soham Bakshi - 6289499093
Snehinh Sen - 9903403125
Samarth Bhat - 9591608436
Amitakshar Biswas - 7003595124
or via email - limit2020.isibangalore@gmail.com

11461001009_EEE F111 » Forums » Announcements » Regarding the solution of Q4 of mid-sem test
Picture of Arnab Hazra . 	
Regarding the solution of Q4 of mid-sem test
  	
PDF document Other Solution of Q.4.pdf

Dear All,

Q4 in the mid-semester exam can be solved by multiple methods. One of the possible solution is delta to Y conversion (or Y to delta conversion) of the load as mentioned in the model solution uploaded on Nalanda by 5th March, 20. Without any Y-delta conversion, the problem can be solved by calculating the line currents for delta load and Y load individually. Final IaA (also IbB, IcC) can be calculated by adding the two line-current components. However, this 2nd method has no conflict with the syllabus attached in the notice before mid-sem. The alternate solution of Q4 with individual line current measurement technique has been attached for your reference.

Therefore, the delta-Y conversion was discussed in lecture classes’ couple of times.  Also, problem number 4.65 based on Y-delta conversion for three-phase load was discussed in tutorial classes’ on 27th and 29th February 2020. So, the concept of delta-Y conversion is a well-discussed method for this course.


 

Best wishes,

Equity Research Initiative
    by
    Mentored-Research
    in collaboration with
    Wall Street Club, BITS Pilani and Finance Comittee, Placement Unit

 

    Mentored-Research is proud to present its flagship program – the Equity Research Initiative (ERI); a 6-week internship-cum-training program designed to train students to perform an educated analysis of equities.

    In operations since 2010, ERI has equipped students from the top colleges of India, including the likes of BITS Pilani, IIT Kharagpur, NIT Trichy, BIT Mesra, VJTI Mumbai, Lady Shri Ram College (Delhi University), etc in the art of equity research.

    Students are taught how to analyze businesses and their respective sectors, screen for comparable companies, read financial statements, use ratio analysis techniques, and construct valuation models. Done right, this will gives students an understanding and insight into the business of the company and its performance relative to industry benchmarks. Students complete the program by compiling their analysis into a stock pitch video, giving them invaluable soft skills. In course of this program, students are also given the opportunity to interact and network with several finance professionals via live online chat sessions.

    Further, students who successfully complete the course will receive a certificate of completion. Beyond the 6 weeks of interactive learning, such a certification will undoubtedly be a lucrative resume addition for any student inclined towards finance, investment banking, stock markets, business consultancy and related avenues.

    Requirements

    There are no pre-requisites to this program, with the only requirements being a passion to broaden your horizons and a willingness to learn.  


        Fundamental Analysis
        Financial Modeling using MS-Excel
        Valuation Techniques
        Equity Research
        Stock Pitch
        Interactive sessions with experienced industry experts


        Introduction to Ms-Excel
        Introduction to Stock Markets and Investing
        Fundamental Analysis
        Ratio Analysis
        Discounted Cash Flow Valuation
        Relative Valuation

    To get a brief idea about the program, check out this video!





    Please fill the form to Register - Click Here
     


    info@mentored-research.com

    wscbppc@gmail.com 
    +91-7738935227

1.     12.5% weightage on the conducted tutorial tests. Out of 3 tuts conducted before mid-semester examination, we will choose the best 2 (30 marks).


3.     Marks scored out of 60 will be weighed against 75 marks, i.e. 25% of the total weightage.


1.     Problems in the take-home assignment will be based on the concepts/topic as discussed in the lecture classes and are given in the textbook A.P. French.

2.     All students are advised to solve the problems on their own.

3.     Students should submit their own hand written assignment to the respective MEOW section instructors via e-mail as a single pdf file (maximum 6 pages and less than 6MB size). Printed version is not acceptable. 


5.     Please keep the handwritten copy safe. You may have to submit it to your MEOW section instructors after you come back on campus.

6.     Maximum time duration to submit the assignment is 2 days. As an example, if you receive the assignment on 7th May 2020 at 12 noon, then you have to submit it via e-mail by 9th May 2020 night 10 PM. Assignment should be posted to you on 7th May 2020 before 12 noon, but time will be counted from 12 noon.

7.     After 2 days (as described), one-day late submission will be accepted with a penalty of 5 marks. This will be activated after the maximum time duration.

8.     In case of any kind of duplicate submission, only 1st submission will be considered.

9.     This assignment is compulsory for all and there is no make-up for this component. 



IC on behalf of MEOW Team

Department of Physics,

BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus.

11461001011_MATH F112 » Forums » Announcements » Regarding assignment submission process
Picture of Ashish Tiwari . 	
Regarding assignment submission process
  	

Dear all,

   I hope all of you are preparing your assignment as per the instructions mentioned. After completing your handwritten assignment and saving the scanned file in pdf format, all of you have to then submit your assignments in the google class platform. Your tutorial instructors are creating classes of each tutorial sections and you will soon get the invitation of your respective class by your tutorial instructors. In the google class of your specific section, your instructor will create an assignment component/task where you are supposed to upload your assignment in the pdf format only. Dear All,

Hope you and your family members are fine and doing well in this unexpected time of crisis due to pandemic. I am sure this difficult time will pass soon with our strength of patience and awareness, and we will meet soon on the campus again with the same cheer and joy.

Many students have asked for my advice regarding the compre option. There are many things to ponder about the compre exam. First, we do not know its time. It may be very near to your next sem exams. Next, out of 45%, it would carry at least 20% open book or  it may be completely open book depending on the situation.  

Considering the above points, in my opinion, you should not opt for the compre exam. The students who have really bad precompre score and are very confident of scoring in open book part of compre exam, may think about the compre option. In my opinion, the compre exam would not create a big difference in your grades rather you will loose the benefit of precompre grading in case you are not able to do well in the compre. You know that scoring in open book exam could be very difficult. So I will suggest all of you not to burden yourself with the compre exam. Forget it, chill and utilize your focus and energy for the courses of the next semester. In case you opt for compre exam, you will always be engaged and worried about the compre exam till it is over. This may badly affect your performance in the next sem courses. 

In conclusion, in my opinion, you should not burden yourself with the compre exam because I do not see any big advantage rather it could be an disadvantage for you due to the reasons I mentioned above.

Cheers,

Suresh

Dr. Suresh Kumar
Associate Professor, Department of Mathematics
BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus, Rajasthan-333031, INDIA.
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄






    Dear All,

    Happy new year! 

    Now you are already experienced about studies and preparation of exams in BITS Pilani. Yet I felt the need to share some tips with you for the study of Probability and Statistics course that can help you a lot to have the real feel and learning of this important course. 

    First you must know and realize very quickly that this course is very very important course having enormous applications in every discipline of science and engineering. For doing any advance course in statistics, this course is a pre-requisite. Feel it a lifetime opportunity to learn this basic and elementary course. So feel yourself motivated to learn the concepts in this course as deep as possible. Once you start listening and reading it carefully,  it is very easy to understand. Trust me you will enjoy it with fun! 

    Now I tell you a short/direct path to reach the level of real learning and enjoyment in this course. First read the notes at the link Chapter 2  word by word, and try to learn all the definitions/concepts cleanly. Try to visualize there how things are developed one after the other. These notes are exclusively prepared for your use. These notes carry nice flow of the development of probability concepts in pedagogical and concise manner. Section 2.1 requires only one careful reading to get an idea of the main objective of the course. After that starting from random experiment learn all the definitions/concepts with examples. Do all the examples in writing with understanding of the concepts. I have taught these notes in the first four lectures in the LTC. So you can also listen the impartus lectures to understand these notes conveniently. If still you face any difficulties in understanding something there, you can write me or come to my office 6165-O around 5 PM on any day (except Saturday and Sunday). I will be happy to help you.

    These days, I am working on the Chapter 3 where I am trying to give a crisp and clear demonstration of all the discrete probability distributions. I am sure you will enjoy this stuff...
     
    I may not be here tomorrow but my words of motivation will always be with you... Will stay in touch with you..

    Cheers! 

    Suresh

    Dr. Suresh Kumar
    Associate Professor, Department of Mathematics
    BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus, Rajasthan-333031, INDIA.

11481001022_MATH F211 » Forums » Announcements » Instructions for Test-1
Picture of Krishnendra Shekhawat . 	
Instructions for Test-1
  	

 

Instructions for Test-1

Test-1 for MATH F211 is scheduled on 14.09.20. It will be conducted through Google classroom. You must have received an Invitation for Test-1 on your registered BITS e-mail i.d.. Accept it as soon as possible. If not, then please contact IC.

 

The Question paper for the Test-I can be downloaded by Clicking on the Tab Stream. The same would be visible under the Tab Classwork.

 

Test-1 will be subjective and you need to solve it on white sheets. Once you are ready with your solutions, first upload them as one file on the Tab Classwork on your registered Classroom by clicking on + Add or create button and then click on Turn in. The file to be uploaded should be of pdf format and name it by BITS i.d.

 

Test-1 is of 45 marks and 30 minutes.  Five extra minutes will be given for uploading the answer sheet. It means, within 35 minutes you need to upload your answer sheet. It will start at 1.10 p.m. and will end at 1.45 p.m.

 

The syllabus for Test-1 is till section 17 (refer to handout).

 

The attendance for Test-1 will be taken through Google meet. On 14.09.20, you need to attend your class in your registered section only. It is mandatory to keep your camera on and mike off. In the chat box of Google meet, you must write your name and I.D. Do not write anything else in the chat box of Google meet and Google Classroom. At any point of time, Instructor may ask you to switch on your mike or to change the angle of the camera.

 

Late submission is not allowed. If for genuine reasons, you won’t be able to upload your answer sheet, then within the time limit, it needs to be sent to IC (9468839182) through WhatsApp. Under unavoidable circumstances, late submission will be considered for the next 5 minutes but with a penalty of 5 marks. Further late submissions won’t be considered for Make-up.

 

At the top of all pages of answer sheets, it is mandatory to mention your name and I.D. Try to use as few sheets as possible for writing the final answers. Answers should be neatly written and should be readable otherwise it may have an impact on your marks.

Mobile Phones can only be used for scanning and uploading purposes. Don’t use it for messages and phone calls.


Any Query regarding Test-I need to be sent through a google sheet only, which will be shared soon.

11481001170_GS F232 » Forums » Announcements » Cognition
Picture of Tanu Shukla . 	
Cognition
  	

Dear students, 

Some of the students had difficulty in viewing the following videos in class today due to network issues. Kindly view the shared links to understand cognition and cognitive development. 

Cognition includes activities and processes concerned with the acquisition, storage, retrieval and processing of knowledge. These help us perceive, attend, remember, think, reason, decide, communicate and so on. 

 Scientists at the Primate Research Center tried to understand the cognitive development in humans and chimpanzees. Humans developed social and language capabilities. Recent cognition and behaviour studies have mentioned that chimpanzees are good at capturing images rapidly as a whole, while humans are better at understanding the meaning of what they see. Chimpanzees neglect social context whereas humans are collaborative, altruistic and using language for communication. The theory provides insights, how humans 'traded' some aspects of cognitive development by re-purposing areas of the brain that evolved in the context of other uses. 





- Tanu

11481001022_MATH F211 » Forums » Announcements » Instructions for Test-II
Picture of Krishnendra Shekhawat . 	
Instructions for Test-II
  	

 Dear Student

The following Instructions will be followed strictly. Please read them carefully.


Instructions for Test-II

Test-II for MATH F211 is scheduled on 12.10.20. It will be conducted through Google classroom. You must have received an Invitation for Test-II on your registered BITS e-mail i.d. from your Lecture Instructor. Accept it as soon as possible. If not, then please contact your Instructor.

 

The Question paper for the Test-II can be downloaded by Clicking on the Tab Stream. The same would be visible under the Tab Classwork (MathIII Test2).

 

Test-II will be subjective and you need to solve it on white sheets. Once you are ready with your solutions, first upload them as one file on the Tab Classwork (MathIII Test2) on your registered Classroom by clicking on + Add or create button and then click on Turn in. If you forget to turn in, then it will not be considered for evaluation. The file to be uploaded should be of pdf format and name it by BITS i.d.

 


 

Late submission is not allowed. If for genuine reasons, you won’t be able to upload your answer sheet, then within the time limit, it needs to be mailed to your Instructor, who will confirm the receiving of your file through Google Meet. Mail sent to any other Instructor will not be considered. Even after sending the mail, you must submit your file to Google Classroom by 2 p.m., 12.10.20. Under unavoidable circumstances, late submission will be considered till 1.48 p.m. but with a penalty of 5 marks. Submissions after 1.48 p.m. won’t be considered.

 

 

The attendance for Test-II will be taken through Google meet. On 12.10.20, you need to attend your class in your registered section only. It is mandatory to keep your camera on and mike off. In the chat box of Google meet, you must write your name and I.D. Do not write anything else in the chat box of Google meet and Google Classroom.

 

At the top of all pages of answer sheets, it is mandatory to mention your name and I.D. If on any page, name and i.d. is missing, it will not be checked.

Mobile Phones can only be used for scanning and uploading purposes. Don’t use it for messages and phone calls.

11481001170_GS F232 » Forums » Announcements » IP T 3 Answer Key
Picture of Tanu Shukla . 	
IP T 3 Answer Key
  	

I.                     Correct sequence (5*2 = 10)


Chunking, sensory register, consolidation, elaborative rehearsal, selective attention

 i)               __________

ii)              __________

iii)            __________

iv)             __________

v)              __________


 


Drive reduction, Need, Drive, Goal achievement, Goal-directed behaviour

___________________________________________

Ans) Need, Drive, Goal-directed behaviour, Goal achievement, Drive reduction


a)     Information reaching the meaning level of processing and elaboration has the best chance of being retained (True)

b)     According to information processing theories of memory, information is transferred from stage to stage until some of it is finally lodged in long-term memory (True)

c)     A specific state within the organism that may elicit behaviour appropriate to the need often as a result of a disturbance in homeostasis is known as a drive. (True)

d)     Working memory is like a workbench where the material is constantly being handled, combined and transformed (True)

e)     Information maintained in the rehearsal buffer is prevented from decaying in STM (True)

III.           Fill in the blanks (12*2=24)

a)     Short term memory holds information for _________ seconds or less (30 s)

b)     A subject is presented four non-sense syllabus one by one each for two seconds. After the presentation of the four items, the subject is asked to count backwards aloud by threes from some number for fifteen seconds and after that he/she is asked to recall the non-sense syllabus. What memory storage is being measured in this experiment? ________ (Short term memory storage)

c)     Needs cause a psychological state or feeling called as _________ (Drive)

d)     Entry of information in long term memory depends on ____________ and __________ (Elaborative rehersal and Primary memory)

e)     Memory that contains factual information is called ____________ (Declarative memory/Semantic Memory) (0.5 – Explicit memory)

f)      Skills that are operated automatically and without thinking are rooted in _______ memory (Implicit memory/Procedural)

g)     Memory for surprising and consequential events (emotional public events) are known as __________ (Flash bulb memory) (0.5 – Episodic memory)

h)     When previous learning interferes with our memory of later learning it is referred to as ________ (proactive interference)

i)      Drive theories of motivation are also known as _____________ (Push theories of motivation)

j)      ___________ theory takes hedonistic view of motivation. (Opponent-process theory)

k)     A condition of drive is brought about in an organism whenever there is ____________ (disturbance/deprivation/need)

IV.            MCQs (7*2=14)

       i.         Working memory involves which of the following?

a.      Storage capacity and Biographical information

b.      Semantic information and Processing capacity

c.      Storage capacity and Processing capacity

d.      Biographical information and Semantic information

     ii.         Which of the following best describes the serial position curve?

a.      Greater accuracy of recall of words in the beginning of the list and in the middle of the list.

b.      Greater accuracy of recall of words in the beginning of the list and gradual diminished accuracy by the end of the list.

c.      Greater accuracy of recall of words in beginning and at end of the list.

d.      Greater accuracy of recall of words in the middle and at the end of the list.

    iii.          According to interference theory, which one of the following causes forgetting?

a.      Failure of storage

b.      Failure of encoding

c.      Failure of retrieval

d.      Response Competition

    iv.  Which of the following can be viewed as a homeostatic mechanism?

a)     hunger

b)     Thirst

c)     Sex

d)     Both a and b

      v.         Which of the following statements is not correct about drives?

a.      Drives beside being stimulated by biological factors, may also be induced by intense internal/external stimuli

b.      In addition to primary drives, we also have many secondary drives

c.      Neutral stimuli paired with strong drives can acquire motivating properties

d.     Primary drives depend on learning

 

    vi.         Fear is an example of

a.      acquired drive

b.      Aversive state of the organism aroused by stimuli that signal a future threatening event

c.      Example of instinct

d.     Both a and b

   vii.         Intrinsic motivation is closely related to the ________ of Maslow’s hierarchy.

a.      Lower levels

b.      Middle Levels

c.      Higher levels

V.             Explain (2 marks)

Episodic buffer refers to _____________________________________

(a component of working memory, is used to integrate and to store briefly the information from phonological loop and visuospatial sketch-pad)

11481001170_GS F232 » Forums » Announcements » IP T4 Answer Key
Picture of Tanu Shukla . 	
IP T4 Answer Key
  	

1. In classical conditioning when a strong CS is paired with a neutral stimulus causing the neutral stimulus to become a second CS is called

a.  Higher Order Conditioning

b. Stimulus Substitution

c.  Vicarious Conditioning

d. Discrimination Learning

2. After several visits to the doctor for chemotherapy, Anita finds that she begins to feel nauseous just sitting in the waiting room. According to classical conditioning, Anita’s feeling of nausea in the absence of chemotherapy is

a.  an unconditioned stimulus

b. an unconditioned response

c. a conditioned stimulus

d.  a conditioned response

3. A parent deliberately ignores a child’s temper tantrums in an attempt to discourage them. The parent’s strategy is in accordance with

 a. Negative reinforcement

b.  Extinction

c.  Operant escape

d. Operant avoidance

4.  Choose the correct behavioural outcomes from the options provided for the procedure mentioned.


i.                Learn to perform responses that produce pleasant outcome

ii.              Learn to suppress responses that lead to unpleasant outcome.

iii.             Learn to supress responses that lead to loss or postponement of desired stimulus

iv.             Learn to perform responses that permit to avoid or escape an unpleasant event.






5. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of Tolman’s theory of learning?

a.  Purposive Behaviour

b. Vicarious trial and error

c. Contiguity

d. Latent learning

6. Mention whether the following belong to the mechanism of operant learning?

a) Events that follow an action (Yes/No) ______ Yes

b) Involuntary response (Yes/No) ______  No

c) Processes that weakens or suppresses behaviour (Yes/No) _______ Yes

d) Use of consequences to strengthen behaviour (Yes/No) _____ Yes

7. True or False (8x1= 8 marks)

a)       Classical conditioning is quick when UCS is presented immediately after CS rather than before. (TRUE)

b)       Organisms learn to suppress responses that lead to removal of pleasant consequences. (TRUE)

c)       Punishment weakens responses that precede occurrence of stimulus. (TRUE)

d)       It is possible for learning to remain dormant for a considerable length of time before it is manifested in behaviour (TRUE)

e)       Reinforcement is not important for latent learning (False)

f)        Latent learning is not translated into performance (True)

g)       According to Bandura, the behaviour is fully determined by mental images of past experiences (False)

h)       Information gained from observations is stored symbolically in retentional processes to make it useful (True)

 

8. Which of the following are the correct explanations of discrimination and stimulus generalizations?  (Yes/No)

(a) Learning to respond to one stimulus but not to the other similar stimuli. ________

 (b) Learning to respond to one stimulus but not to the other different stimuli.  ______

(c) Stimuli similar to the one used during conditioning also elicit the conditioned response.  _____

(d) Stimuli different to the one used during conditioning also elicit the conditioned response. ____



a. Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of (A).

 b. A and R are correct, but R is not the correct explanation of (A).

 c. A is true, but R is false.

d. R is true, but A is false.

 

10. A person rattles the box of dog's biscuits before giving the biscuit to dog. As the person rattles the box the dog begins to salivate. Thus, rattling of box is _____; and the salivation of dog is a kind of _______.


11. Name the Psychologist who proposed the following phenomenon

a)     Observational learning _________

b)     Cognitive Maps _______

c)     Association of different stimuli ________

Ans) Bandura, Tolman, Pavlov

1. It is possible that the students may see the score on aws.nalanda more than the one shown on Dashboard (bits-pilani.ac.in) This because of the negative marking scheme for section 1. Please go through the test properly and then only write back to me if you have any query.
2.There are around 23 students who never submitted the test. Fortunately I could extract their submission from Nalanda and manually done their evaluations hence these students may not be able to see the evaluation on Nalanda.
3. Answer sheets submitted in google drive as well as on Nalanda are evaluated. Those who submitted on Nalanda can see the answer sheet there only. You may be able to see some remarks also with the answer sheet.
4.Answer sheets submitted through email are not evaluated as it was announced well in advance to upload the answer sheets on Nalanda only and form Dummy test was also provided, unfortunately very few students attempted the dummy test.  However, I have checked the answer sheets uploaded on google drive also.
5. Post comprehensive average is 136.88 and comprehensive average is 18.51.
6. If there is any genuine doubt then only write to me.
7. It is difficult for me to share the answer sheets summitted on google drive.
8. Soon you will be able to see the answers on aws.Nalanda
9. Uploading of the marks is in progress wait.

Thanking you  




    Dear Students,
    Please find the marks of Test 2 and Tutorial test on bending attached herewith.

    Dr. Faizan will inform you about the test 3 details.

    One more test on the syllabus of test 1 and test 2 will be conducted as a make up for test 1 and test 2. As the next two weeks are going to be very busy with the tests and submission of other subjects as well as comprehensive examinations of the previous semester, I am planning to conduct the make up test on 14 /11/2020.

    Best 2 out of test1, test 2 and makeup will be considered.

    Please give the suggestions.

    Best Wishes
    Sachin

Three dimensional steady state heat conduction
  	

Dear Students,

As discussed in the class, i am providing the two papers related to the general heat conduction equation.Please refer the same. (You need not understand the paper completely). You can see the governing equation and the temperature distribution in the billet.

Links for the papers are given they are easily downloadable.




I hope you enjoy learning heat transfer with practical applications.

best wishes

P Srinivasan

    Once you get the notification for the same,  write your name, ID number, course name on a page and upload a scanned pdf file of the same page as solutions before 12 PM tomorrow (Jan 25). 
    If you face any issue in uploading the file, let us know by replying to this email before 1 PM tomorrow (Jan 25).



    Dear Students,

    Please edit your profile on CANVAS and carefully enter your personal details. In some cases, email addresses have been entered as student names. Kindly enter your details correctly. 


        Dear Students,

            All the tutorial tests for all sections shall be conducted through the course page on CANVAS. 
            An invitation to join the page has already been sent to you. Check your email inbox.
            If you have not received an invitation or you are facing any issue in joining the course page, share your details by replying to this email.
            You must join the page before the first tutorial class on Monday (Jan 25, 2021).
            Tutorial tests will be posted as assignments on the page.
            Links to recorded videos of tutorials will also be posted regularly on the same page.
            You shall submit your solutions as a single scanned pdf file before the due time for every tutorial test.
            Email submissions will not be accepted.
            Rechecking requests if any shall be submitted by writing a private comment under the marks assigned to you.
            You may also install the CANVAS STUDENT mobile app for students on your mobile device for easy access.

         

        --

Dear Students,

Before writing the instructions, I want to clear one thing the course is running only for two sections (L1 and L2) and fifteen tutorial sections (T2 to T16). The L3 section and T1 tutorial section is for those newly joined 2020 batch students who will enter their second semester in March 2021. In the timetable, it is clearly mentioned that the instructor is decided it means those sections are not currently running.

For those who have added into L3 and T1, that is by mistake and this concern we have raised to the concerned authorities and will soon resolve. For all students, the regular class days are MWF and tutorial class on Tuesday at 8 AM. Therefore, the tut test as mentioned in the course handout will surely be conducted on 9th Feb 2021 at 8 AM. 

The canvas invite link and other quiz specific instructions will be shared with you by tomorrow. You need to accept the invite link and you will be added to the course. The link may be sent by end of the day so wait for it. During tut-test, you need to keep your Video and Audio ON. Your attendance and movement will be watched as per the instructions by AUGSD. 

Please do not ask to relax any instruction. 

All the best

Dear Students,

Those who have not yet accepted the Canvas invite, please accept as soon as possible, otherwise, you will miss this component. 

Following are the final instructions for attempting tomorrow's tut test at 8 AM.


2. Join the respective tutorial class link with your Video ON and Audio ON throughout the test. This will be noted by the invigilators and by the google system.

3. Put your headphones jack in the port so that any voice could not disturb you (don't wear the headphones). In case you want to ask anything, please write to the chatbox. Keep checking the chatbox after every 10 minutes for any announcement.



6. After submission, go back to the Quizzes tab. Within three minutes, a new tab Assignment Quizzes will be visible to you (if not then click on the Quizzes tab again to refresh). Click on the Tut Test 1- 9th Feb 2021 to start the test.

7. Once started, you will be given 30 (thirty) minutes to attempt the 30 (thirty) questions. Each carry one mark. 

8. As per the instructions shared yesterday, one question at a time will be visible. After choosing the correct option, click on the next for the next question. Remember the questions are locked, you cannot go back and change your answer. Also, you cannot leave a question blank by thinking that you will come later and attempt. This is not allowed, therefore optimize your time accordingly.

9. After attempting all the questions you need to click on Submit option. If you do not submit within 30 minutes then it will automatically be submitted and close. Your answers will remain saved within the system. Don't worry. 

10. The exam is an open book exam and all questions are self-explanatory. Please don't ask any doubt. Whatever you interpret, choose the best option.

11. There is No Negative Marking.

12. Join your respective Tutorial section - Those who have mistakenly assigned T1 can join the link given against T17. The changes are notified to the authorities and will be done soon.

Dear Students,

The two students have not yet accepted the Canvas invite, please accept as soon as possible before the test, otherwise, you will miss this component also. 

Following are the final instructions for attempting tomorrow's tut test at 8 AM.


2. Join the respective tutorial class link with your Video ON and Audio ON throughout the test. This will be noted by the invigilators and by the google system.

3. Put your headphones jack in the port so that any voice could not disturb you (don't wear the headphones). In case you want to ask anything, please write to the chatbox. Keep checking the chatbox after every 10 minutes for any announcement.

4. On the Canvas course page, Go to the Quizzes tab showing on your left-hand side in blue color. 


6. Once started, you will be given 30 (thirty) minutes to attempt the 30 (thirty) questions. Each carries one mark. 

7. The quiz instructions remain the same. One question at a time will be visible. After choosing the correct option, click on the next for the next question. Remember the questions are locked, you cannot go back and change your answer. Also, you cannot leave a question blank by thinking that you will come later and attempt. This is not allowed, therefore optimize your time accordingly.

8. After attempting all the questions you need to click on Submit option. If you do not submit within 30 minutes then it will automatically be submitted and close. Your answers will remain saved within the system. Don't worry. 

9. The exam is an open book exam and all questions are self-explanatory. Please don't ask any doubt. Whatever you interpret, choose the best option.

10. There is No Negative Marking.

11. Join your respective Tutorial section - Those who have mistakenly assigned T1 and still not sure about their tutorial section can join the link given against T17.

No Matlab/Python/excel OR any such tools for calculation purpose.

§  Mention as many dimensions as possible. No clarifications/requests regarding the same will be accepted once the examination ends.

Picture of Rahul Arora . 	
  	

Dear Students,



    All the questions are compulsory
    Sections sequencing is fixed so you need to attempt each section one by one and one after the other in a set sequence. You cannot skip any section, however, you can leave the questions unanswered. 
    You will get 105 minutes in total to complete the exam and upload.
    The first section (Part A) is timed and you need to complete all the questions in Part A within the first 40 minutes. The type of questions and their weightage will get to know at the time of the exam. Please do not ask through separate emails. 
    The remaining time is for Part B and Part C consisting of two questions in each part. The suggestion is to allocate the remaining time equally to both sections carrying equal weightage where you need to upload your answers while writing their explanation on the space provided.

    Do not forget to write your Name, ID number, course number, and date on each page of your answer sheet. To get the full score, you need to show all the steps required to arrive at the final answer with proper interpretation.
    All questions are self-explanatory, so write your answer as per your understanding of the question as per the class discussion.
    Online browsing will not be tolerated. If any student will be found with the browsing, her/his paper will not be evaluated. Remember, we are also looking at your screen.
    Don't send your answer sheets to my email during or after the exam. It will not be considered. Please do not ask for this. This is as per the AUGSD guidelines. 
    The Mid-Sem test is Open Book and you can access any study material, provided they are not surfing the internet.
    This evaluative component is proctored so read the Mettl instructions carefully and be alert because you will be watched each time by the invigilators. Please concentrate on your exam only and cooperate with the proctor.


    Please adhere to the guidelines of AUGSD & Timetable related to the Mercer Mettl Platform. Please be ready with all the necessary technology specified by the AUGSD/Timetable for giving an exam on the Mettl platform.
    Be alert and join as per the instructions given while your training on Mettl.
    Please ensure no disturbances during the exam time. Please ensure the highest ethics and maintain the decorum of the exam.


    For those who are not able to join, wait for some time and try after a minute. Don't worry, your time will start once you enter into the exam window.
    For those who are not able to receive the OTP wait for some time, refresh your email inbox, and get it.
    Still, after few minutes you are not getting OTP then click on the link again for getting a new OTP. Do all those things patiently. 
    You can also get 504 error for which wait for some time to connect or again join using the link and new OTP.
    If you disconnect in between because of internet connectivity at your place and if you come out from Mettl by the system itself then wait for the connection and then again log into the system using the link. The link will become inactive for those who didn't join even for a single time. It will remain active for those who join on time and available because of any kind of interruption during the exam time to rejoin.
    Don't be panic. Think patiently and behave. Your time will not go until you successfully login to the system.
    Do the necessary uploading on time. 

All the best
Course Instructors

Dear Students,
I have engaged all the classes as per the schedule except on 15/03/2021 due to some other commitments and wanted to take a compensation class today. ( I have not conducted any extra class beyond the scheduled class). However,We may be able to complete the portion as per the schedule. Hence, I wanted to avoid taking this compensation class.
If needed we will have it at a later date.
There will be a lab quiz on Conduction experiment on 30/03/2021 from 4 PM for 10 minutes and submit your conduction lab record by 23 59hrs of 01/04/2021.
Wish you a Happy weekend and Happy Holi.
best wishes
P Srinivasan

11491002399_ME F221_MF F221 » Forums » Announcements » Eligibility for the 'Clear' Grade
Picture of Amit Rajnarayan Singh . 	
Eligibility for the 'Clear' Grade
  	Dear all
The pandemic has wreaked havoc all over the world and the situation is dire in our country at the moment. The whole semester has been fraught with challenges on the physical, psychological, and social levels for the students as well as the faculty. These are unprecedented times especially in your young lives and there is a need for unprecedented measures on various fronts.


    We have introduced a "Grace Marks Tutorial" component in which the entire class has been given 10 out of 10 marks. Including this component, now we have a total of 5 tutorials.
    We will consider the best 3 out of these 5 tutorials towards your course total.
    The course Gradebook on Nalanda has already been updated to reflect the above changes.
    Every student whose course total is more than 24 is eligible for applying for the "Clear" grade option on the ERP. (Around 97% of the class is now eligible.)


    We are fully aware that some students will opt for writing the comprehensive exam or the make-up exam.
    The grace marks may be a disadvantage for some of these students, in terms of relative grading.
    To address this concern, it has been decided that when we will calculate the "non-clear" grades after the comprehensive exam, THE GRACE MARKS TUTORIAL COMPONENT WILL BE REMOVED i.e. the extra marks that have been provided above (ONLY to make the maximum number of students eligible for the "Clear" grade) will NOT be considered towards the course total.
    What does this mean for you? You should not overestimate your standing or performance in the course based on the grace marks. It is exclusively meant to enable those who want to opt-out of the final exam to use the "Clear" grade option.
    For the final "non-clear" grades, we will follow the marking scheme mentioned in the hand-out i.e. we will take the best 3 out of the 4 evaluative tutorials that were actually conducted.
    I understand that you will have further questions about how marks of the students who will opt-out using the "clear" grade will be accounted for in the final grading. The AUGSD and the head of the departments have already thought about this issue and have come up with ways to ensure that those who choose to write the exam are not at a loss. Those details will be made available later.

Wish you all the best!

- Dr. Amit R. Singh

11491001023_ECON F211 » Forums » Announcements » Instruction for the Tomorrow's (21st May 2021) Comprehensive Exam Scheduled at 3 PM
Picture of Rahul Arora . 	
Instruction for the Tomorrow's (21st May 2021) Comprehensive Exam Scheduled at 3 PM
  	

Dear Students,


    All questions are compulsory
    Part A contains MCQs with No Negative Marking
    Part B contains descriptive/numerical-type questions from the part taught by Dr. Rahul
    Part C contains descriptive/numerical-type questions from the part taught by Dr. Krishna
    Navigation between sections is allowed
    Calculator is allowed
    For Part B and Part C, you need to write your answers in the space provided. You need Not upload your answers separately and no uploading is allowed and available. Please write the main answer in a new line and try to highlight it. We asked questions in such a way that you can manage typing. Also do not forget to explain/interpret your answer. In economics, without interpretation, a number does not have meaning.
    The exam would be of 120 minutes in total. Make sure that in the 120th minute you click the submit/OK button and finish your test.
    Mettl note down your screen activities, your activities, and activities/gadgets present in your room. So please be aware of it and be honest while giving your exam.
    The exam is open book in the sense that you can refer to the slides, e-copy of the textbook during the exam, and other lecture material shared over NALANDA. Any extra material over the internet opened or seen during the exam will be eligible for a penalty in terms of marks. Remember we are looking at your screen activities also.

The syllabus you all knew. The concepts taught post-mid-sem. From the game theory, you can leave the Max-min rule because that requires one class. After the exam, for your information, I would share the two-page notes on this for your learning only.

All the best
Rahul Arora (IC)

Dear Students,
It is nice to connect with you again for an important cause.
ISRO would like to develop technology in certain areas by funding the project as per the attachment. It needs a PI, Co PI and a few interested & motivated students to work on the project for two years. We would like to submit a proposal in the area of Heat Exchanger as per the project number 369 in the attachment.
This mail is to get the willingness of 3-4 students to work on the project if they are interested. I am sure some of you will be keen to work on this project. We have already submitted another proposal on Heat Pipe design in which 4 of your classmates are members of the project.
We hope to get both the projects to work on if sanctioned. You may recall Prof. Chennu has written a book on compact heat exchanger.
If more students express interest, the selection will be made based on the following criteria.
1) CGPA
2) Mark scored in Heat Transfer (PCT) if the student has opted for cleared grade and total marks if they have written the comprehensive examinations. 
3) Interaction with the students
4) Willingness to develop new product and new business venture.
Interested students may mail me directly with the details given above along with a brief resume.
Last date for submission of the proposal is 20 July 2021. Send your details by tomorrow  5PM.
Best wishes
P Srinivasan

Dear Students,

    All the tutorial tests for the course shall be conducted through the course page on CANVAS. 
    An invitation to join the page has already been sent to you. Check your email inbox.
    If you have not received an invitation or if you are facing any issue in joining the course page, share your details by replying to this email.
    You must complete your profile on CANVAS so that your full name appears in the student list. 
    You must join the page before the first tutorial class on Thursday (August 26, 2021).
    Tutorial tests will be posted as assignments on the page.
    You must submit your solutions as a single scanned pdf file before the due time for every tutorial test.
    Email submissions will not be accepted.
    Rechecking requests, if any, shall be submitted by writing a private comment under the marks assigned to you.
    You may also install the CANVAS STUDENT mobile app for students on your mobile device for easy access.


-- 
Regards,
Gaurav Watts,
Assistant Professor,
Department of Mechanical Engineering,

11511002405_ME F317_AUG_2021 » Forums » Announcements » Next class - 7/09/2021
Picture of Saket Verma . 	
Next class - 7/09/2021
  	

Dear Students,

In the next class on Tuesday (7/09/2021), we will be discussing Fuel-air cycle of IC engines. To understand that better it is required that you revise Otto, Diesel and Daul cycles (Air stadard cycles) that you have studied in the previous subjects. You can follow "Chapter-2 Air-Standard Cycles and Their Analysis " of the text book V Ganesan or the same topic from other reference books. Please come prepared.

Best wishes

Dear Students

The class for Tuesday second hour will be held at their respective sections. BITS Embryo is glad to announce 


Jyothi Kalyan Sura


Award-Winning and Critically Acclaimed Technical Director, VFX Artist and Writer

 

as the guest speaker for 3rd Edition of


Being BITSian

                                        An online talk



Taking over the world as a celebrated Technical Director, VFX Artist and Writer he was once walking the same streets as you!
Now, he's back to reveal the wax and wanes of his journey from BITS to Hollywood.


These interactive talks, delivered by the alumni, would most definitely be a special connection to the heart of the attendees. Jyothi will talk about how a BITSian can make use of the various opportunities at the institute to catapult their profiles to be the best in what they aim to do. 

Though this place has evolved a lot, the core feelings and echo of the institute have remained the same over these years. Jyothi will talk about his personal experiences coupled with an informal interaction that would surely benefit all of the BITSians in continuing the legacy. He will also touch upon his career in the film industry and his roles on the celluloid.



Jyothi Kalyan Sura is a storyteller, an engineer, and a leader. 

His love for creative and technical storytelling led him to DreamWorks Animation India, where he worked as a Technical Director (TD) for three years on critically and commercially acclaimed films like How To Train Your Dragon 2, Pokemon Detective Pikachu, X-men Dark Phoenix among others. He left DreamWorks as the only TD to have an artistic demo-reel. Kalyan spent his spare time developing video games, VR, Animation and writing fictional stories - most notably, a 300-page fiction thriller novel, inspired by events in India.

In May 2018, Kalyan completed his Master's in Film Production from USC's prestigious School of Cinematic Arts with a focus on Writing, Directing and Visual Effects. At USC, Kalyan wrote over 15 short films, two feature screenplays and directed five films. He helped over 20 productions in various roles including Sound, Editing and Visual Effects. Kalyan also served as the President of the Visual Effects Society of USC. Possessing a rare blend of technical and creative skills that he can juggle with sophisticated dexterity at will, Kalyan aims to work at the intersection of storytelling and technology.

BITS Embryo warmly welcomes you all! 



Regards,
BITS Embryo

SOCIETY FOR STUDENT MESS SERVICES ELECTIONS 2019-20  
This is to inform all students that the deadline for the submission of nomination forms has been extended to 10 PM, 13th August 2019 (Tuesday). 

Interested candidates are required to submit both a hard as well as soft copy of their nomination forms to members of the SSMS EC before the deadline. 

All candidates who have already submitted their nominations or are planning to submit their nominations before the deadline must also submit their manifestos before 10 PM on August 13th (Tuesday).

A soft copy of the manifesto needs to be mailed at ssms.electioncommission@gmail.com while 3 hard copies of the manifesto need to be submitted to any member of the SSMS EC for vetting.

The GBM can also find attached the election timeline as well as the Election Guidelines for this semester's election process.

SSMS Election Commission

SOCIETY FOR STUDENT MESS SERVICES ELECTIONS 2019-2020 

This is to inform the GBM that polling for SSMS Mess Elections 2019-2020 are slated to happen on 18th August (Sunday) from 2 PM onward till 4 PM. 14 polling booths will be setup for the same. 

    Residents of Malviya C, Malviya B and MSA are supposed to go to Malviya B to cast their votes.
    Residents of SR Blocks A,B,C and D are supposed to go to the common room in SR Block C.
    Residents of Meera are supposed to cast their votes in the Meera Mess.
    For all other bhawans, polling stations shall be set up in their respective bhawans' common rooms. 


Students are reminded that they need to be carrying a pen and their BITS ID card along with them for verification. In the absence of their BITS ID card, members of the GBM must at least have with them a valid photo ID card for verification which will be carried out at the booth itself. 

On the behest of multiple requests from candidates, campaigning on Saturday shall begin from 1 PM instead of 3 PM (as mentioned in the guidelines). This is to allow for some extra campaigning time before the cool-off period sets in. 


If any member of the GBM wishes to come forward to report campaign violations, they are strongly recommended to come forward in person. Preserving the identity of the informer shall be our responsibility. However anonymous claims have to be investigated by the SSMS EC to the best of their abilities before punishments can be handed out.  

Enclosed with this e-mail is the list of candidates (after withdrawals) and the revised election guidelines.  

SSMS Election Commission

Dear All,

Greetings from Practice School Division.

Practice School is a hallmark of the BITS Curriculum. Practice School is an educational innovation seeking to link industry experience with university instruction. Especially the capstone PS-II Program creates the required setting for experiential learning, by providing students with an opportunity to work on relevant assignments in an industry of their choice, under the guidance of professional experts and the supervision of faculty.

PS Division is happy to announce the release of the 7th edition PS-II Chronicles that is a compilation of student, mentor and faculty experience during PS- II in the second semester of the academic year 2018-19.

The students, industry mentors, and PS-II faculty have come-up with write-ups that offer an insight into the learning experience during PS-II.

The student write-ups are a window into the learning outcomes, the gap between academia and industry, and the day-to-day experiences of students as part of PS-II.

Mentor Write-ups reflect their working experience with BITS Students in all aspects of the student knowledge, academic preparation and work ethics.

PSD hopes that these chronicles will help every reader understand the type of work done by students in PS-II and will provide the necessary feedback path that will help bridge the industry-academia gap.

The chronicle is a must-read for Prospective PS-II Students as this will help understand the work that is happening at various PS Stations and what do the PS-II Mentors look for in terms of skill set.  It will help the student make an informed choice when filling the preference forms. The 7th edition of the PS-II chronicles is attached with this mail.

Thank you

 

Prof. Gaikwad Anil Bhanudas

Associate Dean, PSD, Pilani campus

Dear Sir/Maám,

Greetings from Indo-U.S. Science and Technology Forum (IUSSTF)!

As you must be aware, to nurture future innovators and thought leaders in Building Energy Efficiency, the Department of Science and Technology (DST), Govt. of India, has partnered with the Indo-US Science and Technology Forum (IUSSTF) to announce the Building Energy Efficiency Higher & Advanced Network (BHAVAN) Fellowships - a dynamic and transformative program developed to nurture contacts between students and scientists from India and the United States.

The program will provide an opportunity to the best and brightest Indian students and scientists to gain exposure and access to world class research facilities in leading U.S. institutions to promote research and capacity building in the frontline area of Building Energy Efficiency/ Built Environment/ Habitat Energy Efficiency. It will pave the way for the next generation scientists and technologists from India to interact with American peers, thus helping to build long-term R&D linkages and collaborations.


The application deadline is 30th November 2019.If you have any questions, please contact us at energy.fellowship@indousstf.org.

We look forward to your support in facilitating great response to this call. We hope to receive suitable applications from your institution!

Thank you!

Best Regards

Subhashree

BITS Embryo is glad to announce   
An Online Talk By

S Y Balasubramanian

Global Solution Architect lead

 On 
Attributes for Career Success in IT Industry 

In today’s competitive world, finding the right corporate job is the first step towards setting up one’s career path. Once into the corporate world, building a career needs personal attributes beyond one’s knowledge and skills to succeed. This is more so pronounced in the IT Industry, where the assessment and rewarding mechanisms are varied and continuously evolving. Having a grasp on those personal attributes would help an individual to have a good control over their career and methodically set his/her career on a steady growth path.

BITS Embryo, in association with ARC,  invites you to an online talk by Mr. S.Y. Balasubramanian, alumnus of BITS Pilani, now the Global Solution Architect Lead - Health and Public Service of Accenture Technology has over 28 years of work experience in the IT Industry. Having served in several Tier-1 IT firms like Accenture, IBM, Cognizant and TCS, he has rich experience on most cutting edge technologies in the market place like the Cloud, Blockchain, AI, Data Science. The lecture session is aimed at providing an exposure to those key attributes for one's success in the IT industry. A technology enthusiast who comes with a background of having found his way in growing up in the corporate ladder and will share his learning for betterment of those preparing to enter the corporate world. 


Regards,
BITS Embryo

It is our pleasure to announce the call for application for ThinkSwiss Research Scholarships for Indian students.
It would be great if you kindly spread the news to your Bachelor's and Master's students. I am also attaching the A3 Poster for your kind attention. It would be great if can be put up on relevant noticeboards.

ThinkSwiss Research Scholarships
ThinkSwiss Asia-Pacific is a scholarship program managed by swissnex India and the Embassies of Switzerland in Australia & in Singapore. It supports students enrolled at Indian, Australian and Singapore universities who want to go to Switzerland to conduct research.

Funding
This programme is funded by the swissnex network, part of Swiss State Secretariat for Education, Research and Innovation (SERI).

Eligibility
Masters students or undergraduate students who completed 2nd year, currently enrolled in an Indian university or institute.
The scholarship is open to students in all fields.
Has a written confirmation from a Professor at a Swiss university that he/she will accept you for a research stay in his/her group

> Dear Sir/Madam,
>
> We, on behalf of Department of Information Technology and Electronics are happy to announce the 3rd edition of Bengalathon. As you must be aware that Bengalathon is the India's first state level Hackathon, we are happy to present Bengalathon 2019 at the National level competition. This will be second such edition being conducted in successive years. We would also like to thank you and congratulate all your students, for being a part of this platform in all previous editions. Keeping the tremendous response from the past edition in mind, Government of West Bengal in Department of Information Technology and Electronics have further scaled up the opportunity level that young entrepreneurs can leverage from Bengalathon 2019. Top 15 teams are going to get recognized in this edition, while the top three winners getting INR 5 lakhs, INR 4 lakhs and INR 3 lakhs as prize money respectively.
>
> Bengalathon 2019 was launched on 15 August 2019 and will run till 15 November 2019. The registration and idea submission will be closed on 25 September 2019. Selected ideas will go to next (final) round i.e. the prototype demonstration round. The final round will be held in first week of November followed by award ceremony on 15 November 2019 by Honorable MIC Dr. Amit Mitra.
>
> As your institute is one of the premier institutions in the State, Department of Information Technology and Electronics would like to invite participation from your institution in large numbers and help the state in solving social problems through tech solutions.
>
> All the best to participants from your institution. If you have any queries, please write us at bengalathon@wb.gov.in or reach out to our SPOC Mr. Rajesh Swain at 9973828008.
>
>
>
> Best Regards
> Team Bengalathon

Dear Sir/Madam,

 

You are aware that West Bengal has been recorded as a growing destination for Startups in  Last few years. The Government of West Bengal in the Department of Information Technology and Electronics has initiated programs to support this growth of Startups in the State. One of them was a Technology Competition to address public issues called “BENGALATHON”. This is a platform where tech individuals, startups, students can participate to bring in technical innovations.

Bengalathon 2019, is a third edition of the said Tech Competition this year featuring 11 problem statements based on domains such as Health, Agriculture, Emergency Care etc. Top 15 solutions will be chosen for awards amounting to Rs. 18.5 Lakhs, the winners and 1st and 2nd runner up prizes are Rs. 5 lakhs, 4 lakhs and 3 lakhs respectively.

The format of the BENGALATHON 2019 consists of two rounds. The first round concludes on 25 September 2019, whereas the final round is scheduled to be held on first week of November 2019 . The Department of Information Technology and Electronics, Government of West Bengal along with the support of NASSCOM will conduct the final evaluation round in NASSCOM 10K facility in Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, Chennai, Pune and Kolkata. Based on the evaluation results from different cities, top fifteen teams will be felicitated on 15 November 2019, Kolkata .

We invite your esteemed institution to take part in this path breaking event which may open up opportunities to the entrepreneur minds that are being nurtured in the students of your institutions.

The problem statements and key dates of Bengalathon 2019 are provided in Annexure.

For any queries, please reach us at bengalathon@wb.gov.in / +91-9973828008

 

 

With Kind regards

It is our pleasure to inform you that the DAAD has announced its prestigious internship programme “Working Internships in Science and Engineering” (WISE) for undergraduates again this year. The scholarship programme is open to B.Tech students in their 5th or 6th semester and for dual degree/ integrated (Bachelor-Master) programme students in their 5th, 6th, 7th or 8th semester for carrying out a 2–3 month research internship at German universities/state-funded research institutes.

 

Over the last ten years, numerous undergraduate students have benefitted from this programme by gaining invaluable experience and skills after completing their internships under the guidance of German professors.

 

Applications are invited from 80 elite institutes all over India, including your institution.

 

With your kind support we received over 400 applications last year and we are glad to inform you that approximately 130 scholarships were awarded. We look forward to a similar response this year as well.

 

Attached are copy of the announcement and some guidelines of this programme for your information.

 

We would be grateful if you could forward and circulate the announcement and the guidelines in your institute.

 

Kindly note the deadline for application is 1st November 2019. The online portal to fill in the application opens around 23rd September 2019.

 

Thank you for your cooperation.

 

 

Viele Gruesse/ Kind regards,

 

Ms Ishika D Monty

Scholarship Officer

Dear Faculty and Students,

You would be happy to know that Department of CSIS, BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus is organizing a premier workshop on Deep Learning at BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus during Dec 15-18, 2019.

The workshop is named Indian Workshop on Applied Deep Learning (IWADL-2019) and it is in its third meeting. Earlier two times it was conducted at IIT Mandi. The workshop targets motivated professionals, scholars at Undergraduate/master/Ph.D. level and faculty members who want to pursue work in the area of advanced machine learning. Researchers and experts from various premier Indian institutes (such as IIT Delhi, IIT Jodhpur, IIT Mandi, LNMIT Jaipur, BITS Pilani, etc.) have confirmed their participation as a resource person. The workshop will have intense lectures and hands-on sessions on both basic and advanced topics. The aim is to give exposure to recent advances in the area of deep learning to the participants.

IWADL provides an excellent opportunity to interact with the leading researchers to discuss and explore the state-of-the-art in the focused area. It is going to be great learning with fun.


Please join and spread a word of mouth for the same. Attaching the workshop flyer, please put it at appropriate forums.

Best Wishes
(Dr. Kamlesh Tiwari)
Convener IWADL-2019 Pilani

Dear Students,

 

The Indian Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ISHRAE) was established to promote the HVAC industry in India. ISHRAE is an associate of ASHRAE. The American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, which is an international technical society for all individuals and organizations interested in HVAC. The Society, organized into regions, chapters and subchapters, allows exchange of HVAC knowledge and experience for the benefit of the field’s practitioners and the public. 

 

India is the eleventh largest economy in the world, in terms of purchasing power. HVAC being the major source of power consumption domestically and commercially is rapidly gaining attention worldwide. The HVAC industry has immense opportunities and requirement for skilled professionals, who can contribute towards a sustainable future.

 

With the aforementioned motivation and vision, we are glad to announce the formation of ISHRAE - BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus Chapter.
